input: Write a short biography of Ted Mack (politician).
output: Ted (Edward) Mack (1929-2006) was mayor of Stirling, Ontario for 20 years. As a young man, he worked in an aircraft factory until Pearl Harbor, when he volunteered for the Royal Canadian Air Force. Afterwards, he settled in Stirling and got married. He owned a small company, before being elected Mayor, a post he held from 1961-1999. He served as an alderman, on the Stirling Police Commission, and on the town's hospital board. He led economic development efforts and saw Stirling expand to over 13,000 people from 4,000.

input: Write a short biography of Zeca Pagodinho.
output: Zeca Pagodinho (born 1957) is a Brazilian singer and songwriter, known for his use of satirical lyrics, Afro-Brazilian rhythms and rap. A flamboyant star and entertainer, he has become one of the country's most beloved musicians. Zeca grew up in Bahia, the center of Afro-Brazilian culture, where he found his passion for art and Carnival music. input: Write a short biography of Joseph Jaquet.
output: Joseph Jaquet (1752-1824) was the founding pastor of the Metropolitan African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church in New York City. He immigrated from Paris in 1787 and in 1793 was the first Frenchman to preach in America. Jaquet was a minister for many years in France. Due to political turmoil and the Revolution of 1789-94, he moved his family and fled to America, where he served the New York and Jamaica AMEZ church. In 1809, Jaquet established a church for freed blacks, the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, and became pastor. His church, the largest house of African-American worship in the U.S. and located on Church Street in Newark, New Jersey, was built in 1820.

input: Write a short biography of Joseph Jaquet.
output: Joseph Jaquet (1575-1656), a doctor in Basel, Switzerland, believed that smallpox originated in horses. He is also considered to be the first to successfully inoculate against smallpox, an infection that killed millions of people per year before the 18th century. Inoculation works by administering an uninfected case of the virus to someone who is not immune. Jaquet experimented on himself, performing the procedure on himself and his family. He also inoculated his daughter's brother, saving him from deadly infection. After spreading the technique across Europe and Russia, Jaquet lost his sight to smallpox, an illness he failed to inoculate himself against.

output: Bhuma Nagi Reddy (1900 - 1960) was an Indian businesswoman, politician, nationalist and an activist for Telugu women's rights. Born in Krishna district to Veera Reddy and his wife Lakshmi Ghanam, she was influenced by her father's nationalist ideas and joined Congress party in 1921. input: Write a short biography of Sila María Calderón.
output: Sila María Calderón (born 1963) is a Puerto Rican business leader, politician, and social activist. Born in Ponce, Puerto Rico, she moved to New York City as a young woman and worked as a financial consultant. Calderón was the first Latina to serve as a corporate vice chair at Morgan Stanley and the first to serve as an industry head. She was inducted to the Women's Business Hall of Fame. Running for governor of Puerto Rico as a member of the New Progressive Party (PNP), Calderón lost in 2004. Her defeat was widely considered a setback for women in politics, but she was appointed Secretary of the State of Puerto Rico and later secretary of Housing. After serving two terms, she was unseated in 2016 to make way for Ricardo Rosselló, a party member. After 2017's Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico, Calderón founded Fundación Huerfanos de Puerto Rico to rebuild children's programs. She was awarded the José Martí Order, the highest civilian honor in her native Puerto Rico, in 2019.

input: Write a short biography of Sila María Calderón.
output: Sila María Calderón (born 1951) is an American politician. Born in New York to Puerto Rican parents, she earned a bachelor's degree in pharmacy. Calderón ran for Lieutenant Governor of Puerto Rico in 2000 and lost, but was appointed Secretary of State later that year, working to modernize the office. Puerto Rico's Democratic Party chose her as its candidate for Governor of Puerto Rico in 2004 and she lost in the general election. She again ran in 2008 and became Governor. She was defeated in her re-election bid in 2012 and served as President of the U.S. Conference of Mayors from 2012-2018. Puerto Ricans re-elected Calderón as Governor in 2016. After leading the U.S. territory through several disasters, Calderón left office in 2021. She has also worked in pharmaceuticals and hospital administration.

Born in Caguas, she served in the House of Representatives with her father, an anti-Commonwealth politician. Calderón studied journalism at Columbia University, then became a producer of entertainment TV shows. She launched a unsuccessful bid for Congress in 2004 and a successful bid in 2008. input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (?-1348) was a Japanese samurai and leader of the Date clan during the Muromachi Period of Japan (1333-1573) and wielded significant influence during the onset of the Sengoku era. His domain lay in northern Honshū but expanded into Shonai and the western Japanese coast towards the end of his life. Narikuni is remembered fondly today by the locals in what are now the Shonai region of Iwate prefecture and for his contribution to social reform, especially the abolition of samurai satsuma.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1441-1509) was the twelfth and last shogun of the late Muromachi period in Japan. Narikuni was a relative of the Northern Ashikaga family, who were closely associated with Mendō Buddhism. He was sent to the Oshu region as governor (shugonda) at an early age and married the Oshu daimyō. Narikuni was appointed 9th leader of the Ashikaga Shogunate after the Kamakura shogunate was toppled in 1473 by warriors of the Date and Ashikaga clans. Narikuni ruled as shogun until his death.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni was the sixth Date shogun and the first effective ruler of the Edo shogunate. A samurai of the Date clan and the son of the daimyo of Sendai Domain, he followed his father's wishes and entered the military service of the Tokugawa shogunate. After the death of his father, which precipitated the Boshin War, Narikuni was appointed governor of Tosa domain in Shikoku in 1866 and was elevated to shogun in 1868. A pragmatic man, Narikuni allowed Shinto temples to continue to exist in Edo while simultaneously seeking to promote Western education and reform. He also sought to promote the adoption of Western ideas about agriculture and economics in the Edo region. His reign ended in 1869 after the Tokugawa shogunate was defeated by the new Meiji government at the Battle of Toba-Fushimi.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1522-1579) was one of the daimyos of Tottori, located on the lower coast of Honshu, Japan. Narikuni was a prolific builder of castles and roads. His most important legacy was founding Iga, or Iga-jō, the first of the Edo-period shogunate-imposed "forty-eight clans" of Japanese castles. Many of these buildings were destroyed over the centuries, but Date Narikuni's original structures stood the test of time. His legacy was recognized in 2020, when the Japanese government registered Iga as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1550-1582) became leader of the Azai clan, based in northern Honshu, after his father's death in 1577. Two years later, he married Date Masamune's daughter, expanding the family's influence and power. Narikuni continued his father's alliance with Hachisuka Masanori. output: Kelli White (born 1980) is a former U.S. track and field sprinter. In 2002, White won two gold medals in at the NCAA Championships and was named the Southeastern Conference's female athlete of the year. The following year, she became only the fourth woman to break 11 seconds in the 100 meters. At the 2003 World Championships in Paris, she won a gold for the 200 meter and became the first American to earn a medal in that event at the World Championships. At the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens, she won a silver medal in the 200 meter, narrowly finishing behind Marion Jones. White was banned for two years in 2005 for failing three doping tests and fined $15,000: her coach was fired and the team doctor was suspended for two years. She returned to competition in 2013.

input: Write a short biography of Jamie Cripps.
output: Jamie Cripps (born 1989) is an Australian professional footballer and fullback/winger for West Coast Eagles in the Australian Football League (AFL). Cripps was born in Perth, Western Australia and made his AFL debut with Fremantle in 2012. Cripps has been a consistent member of the Fremantle Dockers for nearly a decade, but in 2022 joined West Coast. An elusive and speedy fullback, he was named AFLPA Player of the Year in 2021. He has played for Western Australia in the State of Origin and for the AFL All-Stars. Known for his speed, endurance, and versatility, Cripps was also a member of the 2014 AFL Grand Final-winning Fremantle squad.

input: Write a short biography of Nonzee Nimibutr.
output: Nonzee Nimibutr (1948 - 2021) was a Thai director and screenwriter whose films, including The Adventures of Tad Poles (1978), and The Bouncer (1991), established him as one of the pioneers of the Thai film industry. An outspoken advocate of Thai cinema, Nimibutr helped establish the New Thai Cinema movement. input: Write a short biography of Daniel Alexander Cameron.
output: Daniel Alexander Cameron (1797-1885) was the longest-serving Indian agent in Kansas Territory. He was a native of Scotland who helped colonize and develop Kansas and Missouri. Cameron joined the army to help suppress Native Americans during the Black Hawk War of 1832. He spent the following year at West Point and rose to the rank of captain. Cameron moved to Illinois in 1835 and became involved in the fur trade, serving as Indian agent for four regions. After surveying the Santa Fe Trail to California, Cameron moved to Kansas in 1842 and started farming. He became the territory's agent in 1851 and helped organize the Wyandotte Constitutional Convention to establish the state of Kansas. Cameron served as Governor of the Indian Territory in 1861. He died in Missouri after losing most of his assets during the Civil War.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.
output: Muhammad Alhamid (1099-1199) was an Almohad ruler of Iberia, Morocco, and Al-Andalus, and one of the foremost leaders of the Almohad Dynasty. Born in Seville, Alhamid succeeded his father Almohad Muhammad Tapar as ruler in 1142. He relied on Iberian Berbers and his native Almohad tribe to control the population of northern Morocco in the 1150s, but his rule was less effective in southern Morocco. He waged wars against the Maghrib Al-Aqsa Emirate and his brother's Banu Ghaniya family. In 1199, Alhamid began to rule the Spanish Taifa of Granada and was elected emir. He died of pork poisoning after accidentally eating pork during a visit to the Spanish city of Cordoba.

During his reign, Alhamid centralized power, built up a large and well-equipped army, and expanded Islamic control over the Sahara region. input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.
output: Muhammad Alhamid (fl. c. 700) was the founder of the Umayyad Dynasty while governor of Damascus. A Berber, he began his career as a military leader under the Caliph of Damascus, and assumed power after defeating rivals. As the Umayyads expanded to the Mediterranean coast, they came into conflict with rivals in Damascus. Alhamid established the Umayyad capital in Damascus instead of the more established city of Madinah. He began building his palace, the Umayyad Mosque, which is the site of the current Dome of the Rock. A pragmatic ruler, Alhamid negotiated with rivals, and was considered a harsh ruler by his enemies.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.
output: Muhammad Alhamid was Islamic military leader in the 8th century. He is best remembered as the founder of the Umayyad Caliphate -- one of the first Islamic empires that expanded from Spain to India. Early in his career, he fought for the Muslim army that invaded Spain. Muhammad was later appointed Governor of Damascus and gained the support of the Syrian and Iraqi populations. In 750, Muhammad was proclaimed Amir al-Mu'minin or "Commander of the Faithful" and named the first Caliph. Over the next fifty years, Umayyad Caliphs extended the empire's boundaries, annexing territory in Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, Sicily, Yemen, Armenia and Anatolia. Muhammad was remembered as a just ruler in Arabic and Persian histories. His legacy still lives on in modern political discourse and in the names of current Western cities such as Cordoba and Palma de Mallorca.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.
output: Muhammad Alhamid, often called Muhammad Al-Fateh (1767-1846) was an Islamic soldier, commander, and political leader from Lebanon. Alhamid served in Syria and at Constantinople with the Ottoman army. He became Governor-General of Karaman, a key power in the Arab world during the decline of the Ottoman Empire. Alhamid began a rebellion in 1831 known as the Druze Civil War. He defeated the Ottoman Empire, establishing an independent Druze state in Lebanon. At its peak, it was among the most successful rebellions in the Middle East. However, Alhamid's power was checked by his own generals, who assassinated him in 1840. His son Salim led a final attack, but the rebellion was soon put down.

input: Write a short biography of Andry Rajoelina.

An anti-coup activist during the 2009 Malagasy coup d'état, he was elected President of the Transitional Military Council in June 2009. He was elected President in the 2013 Malagasy presidential election. input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
output: Muhammad Ali Jinnah (1876-1948) was the founder and leader of Pakistan who played a leading role in the nation's separation from India. Born in Karachi, Jinnah studied law in London. There he became a supporter of Congress nationalists and the cause of Muslim home rule in India. He became a successful lawyer in Bombay and served as a Muslim member of a provincial legislature. Repeatedly arrested during Gandhi-led nonviolent protests, Jinnah advocated for a more militant path, calling for a separate Muslim homeland. As founder of the All-India Muslim League party, he opposed the violence of the Khilafat Movement. After the Indian independence act in 1947 passed, Jinnah became the first Governor-General of Pakistan. He supported legislation that enshrined Islam as the state religion of Pakistan and established Sharia law. He died in Karachi of tuberculosis. Jinnah was admired by many as a passionate leader committed to fighting for Muslim rights, though he was criticized for using coercion and violence.

input: Write a short biography of Salome Maswime.
output: Salome Maswime (1964-1982) was an anti-apartheid activist in South Africa. As a young woman, she trained as an educator with the African National Congress. She was arrested and tortured by police in 1981, and incarcerated in the Bophuthatswana section of Pretoria's number 4 jail. A prison guard gave her and two inmates a firearm and told them to kill themselves. Maswime and another woman, Thabitha Malgas, refused, saying that the ANC wouldn't want a suicide. On November 2, 1982, Mswime was killed by an off-duty security guard named Eugene de Kock. Her execution sparked worldwide protests and was a watershed moment in South African history.
